qas.question: What is another name for canon law?
What is another name for Roman law?
Where could one study Roman law in 1100?
In what century was the Corpus Juris Civilis rediscovered?

context: Legal studies advanced during the 12th century. Both secular law and canon law, or <a0_0>ecclesiastical law<a0_0/>, were studied in the High Middle Ages. <a1_0>Secular law<a1_0/>, or Roman law, was advanced greatly by the discovery of the Corpus Juris Civilis in the <a3_0>11th<a3_0/> century, and by 1100 Roman law was being taught at <a2_0>Bologna<a2_0/>. This led to the recording and standardisation of legal codes throughout Western Europe. Canon law was also studied, and around 1140 a monk named <a4_0>Gratian<a4_0/> (fl. 12th century), a teacher at Bologna, wrote what became the standard text of canon law—the Decretum.
